name: Kate Middleton
religion: Middleton is an Anglican/Episcopalian, the traditional religion of British royals.
politicalViews: Middleton, as a member of the British royal family, is not allowed a political preference--at least in public.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Kate Middleton, now officially Catherine, Duchess of Cambridge, was born in Reading, England and grew up in Amman, Jordan and Berkshire, England.

content.sourceTitle: Kate Middleton Confirmed In Church Of England
content.text: Middleton is now officially a member of the Church of England, an Anglican/Episcopalian church. She was confirmed shortly before her marriage to Prince William.

content.sourceTitle: Why It Matters that Kate Middleton Can Be Catholic Now
content.text: There was some concern and speculation over Kate's religion. Up until the day of her wedding to Prince William, it was British law that a member of the royal family could marry someone of any religion, except Catholic.

content.sourceTitle: Kate Middleton's Secret Confirmation: How Religious Is the Future Princess?
content.text: The worry of certain British people about her religion is a testament to the lack of faith of Kate and her family. It was reported that her parents, though married in an Anglican church, do not regularly attend services.

content.sourceTitle: Kate Middleton's Secret Confirmation: How Religious Is the Future Princess?
content.text: But the concern was really more about prying, nosy British people getting their gossip fix than anything substantial. Kate was baptized in an Anglican church at five months old.

It is true that her confirmation was probably all for show as confirmation is an Anglican ritual designed to show one's deep devotion and faith to Jesus Christ and the Anglican Church and is usually done at a relatively young age, sometimes into a person's teenage years.

content.sourceTitle: Ancestry of the Duchess of Cambridge
content.text: Furthermore, one of Kate's distant ancestors is Reverend Thomas Davis, who wrote some of the Church of England's standby hymns.
No Politics for Britain's First Family

content.sourceTitle: 10 Things Kate Middleton Can't Do After the Wedding on sylvs' Blog
content.text: As a member of the royal family, Middleton is barred from a great many things. One of these things is politics in all of its forms. Middleton is not allowed to vote, to run for office, to endorse a candidate, or in any way make a political statement.
British royals are required to be neutral and cannot be perceived as interfering in the British democratic process.

content.sourceTitle: Royal Wedding Guest List: Obama, Former British Prime Ministers Among Notable Snubs
content.text: One contoversy might have shown Kate and William's political preferences, though it is all merely speculation. The two declined to invite U.S. president Barack Obama and his wife to their wedding, something that was come to be known as a "snub of historic proportions."
The reason presented for the snub was that the astronomical cost of security to retain the Obama's was too much for the royal family. But they are quite wealthy, so one wonders.
